text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new schoolboy q
album oxymoron schoolboy q is a West
Coast rapper member of the infamous
black hippy signed to Top Dawg
entertainment one of the bigger rap
labels out there right now I hope at
this point we don't really need to go
into that deep of an introduction and Q
really broke out with his last
full-length LP Ananda velena habits &
contradictions but habits I was sort of
on the fence with I didn't find this
record to have that much in terms of
personality substance but since habits &
contradictions I've heard Q progress
with many impressive features on
projects like control system and the
heist watching movies with the sound off
rare chandeliers level of ASAP trap Lord
and of course how can any of us forget
yeah yeah yeah yeah and even though I
thought these features were
attention-grabbing I wouldn't say it was
because schoolboy q is a super technical
flashy dude and as far as wordplay goes
most of his verses can sort of be taken
for face value sometimes he is
unashamedly blunt on his song sort of
like the really smooth catchy sort of
sexy track studio on this LP with a very
nice sensual hook from bj the chicago
kid q drops a line in the midst of this
track were you saying I'm going to be
straight into the point with you I'm
going to put this dick all up inside of
you
poetry and even though I think some
people will listen to songs like studio
and think that they really lack in terms
of substance and grit there are songs on
here where Q brings exactly that like
Hoover Street a song where he's rapping
about being young growing up in his
grandmother's house we're also living is
his drug-addicted
thieving and violent uncle Q's lyrics
all over this track are incredibly vivid
I love the murky bass on this thing and
some of the very weird grimy
synthesizers on this track to just make
the instrumental just the overall vibe
of this track sound like L sounds like
hell and Schoolboy Q enhances that with
his really raspy voice on the hook here
anything that really stands out it's
that rasp on a lot of tracks here for
whatever reason it could be his subject
matters on this track it could be the
way he's delivering over these songs but
he was just sounding way bolder more
confident on this LP he is just going in
on some of these songs and sometimes
when he's really pushing that aggressive
envelope these tracks can feel like
they're just on the verge of being
obnoxious with this really over-the-top
energy level but for me it never really
pushes past that line there are songs on
here that I love like gangsta which
kicks this LP off with all these
overdubbed yells and screams over very
slow moody piano groove
I love lows awesome one of the best
tracks on here Pharrell produced the
beat but the instrumental sounds like
Swizz Beatz on meth the song is almost
too dense and cacophonous to handle but
I love the hand percussion and the beat
on this thing the groove is just so
infectious and j-rock sounds fantastic
on the song too and then there's break
the bank a really sweet track with
another slow piano arpeggio playing
throughout it snappy boom bap B Q just
kills all over this track with gritty
rhymes being in your face and and sort
of exposing how potentially short his
rap career could be by being really
frank about it and he also brings what I
think is one of the better hooks on this
entire LP while yeah I think he can rub
some people the wrong way with yeah did
I do that it uh I think it works really
well
oddly enough I know that a lot of songs
on this LP emphasize delivery over
lyrics and substance a little bit and I
know not everybody is going to like that
but I don't think it was a bad move for
him if a more extreme delivery is going
to be what makes schoolboy q more
memorable then do it because I think
he's gone from sort of scatterbrained
and forgettable on his last LP to
versatile and gutsy on this LP even if
he's not an incredibly substantive
rapper the way that I see it he's never
going to be as conceptual as Kendrick
Lamar he's never going to be as heady as
absol so just let him hone that thuggish
side
and if he's going to keep his songs in
that gangsta rap genre the least that he
could do is approach it with the
uncompromising gritty authenticity that
it deserves and he does that I really
think schoolboy q is coming through the
record where a lot of the tracks bring
back that vivid vulgarity of 90s gangsta
rap but with progressive production and
just a more bizarre delivery at times
case in point the title track of this
thing now I love the harder tracks on
this LP they are my favorites
without a doubt but there are some songs
on here that are a little
middle-of-the-road
songs like hell of a night and Man of
the Year hell the night has an
atmospheric trap instrumental which has
a driving kick drum on the hook that
feels a little Club friendly and while I
don't mind cues versus all over this
track the hook is pretty much just
filler for me lyrically as well as Man
of the Year - I actually think it gets
kind of redundant by the end of the song
when the song is over I feel like I've
listened to more hook than verse on this
thing
I do think cue sounds comfortable on
both of the tracks though and I think
both of the instrumentals fit really
well into the LP especially Man of the
Year being the closing track of this
entire album and feeling really final
having a really blissful tone to it and
I say this song is the last song and not
[ __ ] LA or any other track because I'm
listening to just the normal 12 song
version of this LP and the reason that
is is because immediately after man of
the year the song quality pretty much
goes as far as the non deluxe version of
this LP goes I have to say I was pretty
happy with what songs actually made it
onto the album versus the bonus tracks
because the only track here that I think
really derails the album a little bit is
what they want I love the very nocturnal
trap inspired instrumental on this track
but the 2 Chainz verse here is just too
awful for words but I do like how this
track doesn't feel as middle-of-the-road
as other songs on here because it is
gritty ER and that gritty side the
schoolboy q brings does have sort of a
somber and and cold and quiet side -
like on the song blind threats with
Raekwon ray adds a lot toward the
and of this track and I think Q does a
good job of exploring the more emotional
and conflicted side of his persona which
he also does on the song prescription a
heartbreaking track where he's sort of
depicting himself unplugging from his
family and from his work because of his
addiction to prescription drugs sort of
a narrative that we may be familiar with
already but still I think it goes over
well on this song with a very powerful
instrumental also blind threats I have
to mention does have a fantastic
instrumental to with some really great
strings that color the finish of the
song very nicely I think it's great that
schoolboy Q's delivery and personality
is just sort of out there and high
enough to the point where he can go
toe-to-toe with legends like corrupt and
and Raekwon sort of not be totally
destroyed on every single track and q
sounds great with Kendrick - on the song
collard greens a single that I was not
hot on initially when I just heard it by
itself but in the context of this album
I really liked it it's one of the more
interesting rap beats I've heard over
the past year definitely one of the more
progressive sounding songs to ever come
out of TDE with it's very pumping
non-traditional groove when it comes to
at least a hip hop song and I have to
give it up to the song the purge to
which Tyler the Creator does the hook on
this track he does the instrumental on
this track another very cold dark gritty
moment on this LP that cue sounds
fantastic and and really sort of manic
on overall even though the sell p is not
that conceptual it's not that deep or
anything like that though there are some
fantastic and very personal moments lay
down a few of the tracks here I think
the schoolboy q drew together a really
solid set of song I'm feeling a strong
